creditline: Gift of the Clark Center for Japanese Art & Culture; formerly given to the Center in memory of Dorothy Ann "Dot" Schafer
description: white falcon at UR in twisting dive after large white goose at center; goose is lunging downward with legs splayed and mouth wide open; large clumps of fluffy snow fill scene; snow-covered foliage at bottom
medium: Two-panel folding screen; ink, color, and gofun on silk
text: Fukuda Suikō was born in Kyoto where he studied at the Kyoto School of Fine Arts and Crafts. He worked in Kyoto as a print designer and painter, and regularly contributed works to the Exhibition of the Ministry of Education, Bunten (renamed the Imperial Exhibition, or Teiten, in 1919 ). This institution, modeled on the Salon in Paris, was a measure of the artistic mainstream of that time. Birds painted in a realistic and traditional style were Suikō’s predominant subject. This particular screen captures the so-called ‘Three whites’ (sanpaku), a popular painting maxim depicting three elements of white color such as snow, white plum blossoms, or birds. In this case it depicts a goose pursued by a falcon against a wintery background. The goose tries to escape, but the falcon in the opposite corner follows it at a steep angle, creating a strong diagonal movement across the screen. The whole scene is scattered with heavy snowflakes, in the foreground accented with the pastose application of white calcium carbonate pigment, known as gofun. The grasses and branches with red berries in the lower right corner also correspond with the winter theme.
title: Gyrfalcon Hunting a Goose in Snow
